metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (leaf area index of Sidaoqiao, 2018)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the LAI measurements from the Sidaoqiao in the downstream of the Heihe integrated observatory network from June 16 to October 18 in 2018. The site was located in Ejina Banner in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 870 m. There are 2 observation samples, around Sidaoqiao superstation (101.1374E, 42.0012N) and Mixed forest station (101.1335E, 41.9903N), each of which is about 30m×30m in size. Five sub-canopy nodes and one above-canopy node are arranged in each sample. 
The LAI data is obtained from LAINet measurements following four steps: (1) the raw data is light quantum (level 0); (2) the daily LAI can be obtained using the software LAInet (level 1); (3) the invalid and null values are screened and using the 7 days moving averaged method to obtain the processed LAI (level 2); (4) for the multi LAINet nodes observation, the averaged LAI of the nodes area is the final LAI (level 3).
The released data are the post processed LAI products and stored using *.xls format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Qu et al. (2014) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to observe energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used in oasis–desert ecosystems involves the use of an eddy covariance system and scintillometer to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data. Additionally, hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, and other parameters, are observed from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting long-term observational data in arid and semiarid inland river basins?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced in these regions includes ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, as observed in river basins like the Tarim River basin and the Aral Sea basin.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset that supports research in the oasis–desert areas of the HRB?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset supporting research in the HRB includes energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations, hydrometeorological data, and vegetation and soil parameters, which are freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is the role of an eddy covariance system in data collection for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is used to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data, which are crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Definition.Question: How are observational datasets from oasis–desert systems typically processed and quality controlled?
Definition.Answer: Observational datasets from oasis–desert systems are processed and quality controlled through a procedure that includes data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using the LAINet wireless sensor network for leaf area index measurements compare to the eddy covariance system and scintillometer used for energy, water vapor, and carbon flux observations?
Comparison.Answer: The LAINet wireless sensor network collects leaf area index data through automated light measurements at multiple canopy nodes, processing data daily and averaging over time to mitigate weather impacts. In contrast, the eddy covariance system and scintillometer are used for half-hourly measurements of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, focusing on turbulent flux data collection and involving extensive supplementary hydrometeorological and vegetation data for comprehensive ecosystem analysis.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges faced in maintaining the ecological balance in oasis–desert systems compare to those encountered in data collection for ecological and environmental monitoring in arid regions?
Comparison.Answer: Both scenarios involve significant challenges; maintaining ecological balance in oasis–desert systems involves addressing degradation, desertification, and water scarcity. Data collection for ecological monitoring must cope with these environmental variations and ensure accurate, long-term data for understanding ecosystem dynamics. Both require integrated approaches to manage the inherent complexities of arid environments and support sustainable development.

Interpretation.Question: How might the availability of long-term datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange inform strategies for sustainable development in oasis–desert regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The availability of long-term datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange can inform strategies for sustainable development in oasis-desert regions by offering a comprehensive view of ecosystem interactions and resource utilization. This data aids in identifying trends and potential imbalances in ecological and economic activities, facilitating informed decision-making for maintaining ecological security and promoting sustainable growth.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a wireless sensor network like LAINet for collecting leaf area index data over manual observation methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of a wireless sensor network like LAINet allows for automated and continuous data collection at each node on a daily and hourly basis, which enhances the accuracy and temporal resolution of the leaf area index measurements. This approach reduces the possibility of human error and provides a comprehensive dataset that can be processed to remove invalid values and smooth out weather-related fluctuations, resulting in a more reliable assessment of vegetation dynamics over time.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain long-term observations of oasis–desert ecosystems using advanced hydrometeorological sensors?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observations are indispensable for understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is critical to achieving sustainable oasis development and supporting the ecological security and sustainable development of these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the data collection process structured for capturing leaf area index in arid regions using wireless sensor networks?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection process for capturing leaf area index in arid regions using wireless sensor networks involves deploying the LAINet system, which captures light data at each node automatically every hour of the day. The raw data (Level0) is processed using LAINet software to calculate daily LAI at each node (Level1), followed by invalid value identification, filling, and a 7-day moving average to mitigate weather impacts (Level2). The final value for each sub-area is derived from averaging data across multiple LAINet nodes (Level3).

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key procedures followed to ensure data quality and consistency in long-term hydrometeorological observations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The key procedures for ensuring data quality and consistency in long-term hydrometeorological observations include using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for half-hourly flux data, and automated weather stations for hydrometeorological parameters with a 10-minute average period. Data collection is supplemented by vegetation and soil parameters, followed by rigorous data processing, quality control, archiving, and sharing protocols.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to balance the ecological and socioeconomic needs in oasis–desert systems through data-driven research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Methods employed to balance the ecological and socioeconomic needs in oasis–desert systems involve quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange through long-term observational datasets. These datasets, collected from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems, facilitate the analysis of interactions and support sustainable development goals by maintaining ecological stability and socioeconomic viability.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements allowed the effective monitoring and collection of leaf area index data in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of the Leaf Area Index wireless sensor network (LAINet) enabled the automatic collection of hourly light data at each node, facilitating the monitoring of leaf area index in arid regions.

Enablement.Question: How do observational datasets from oasis–desert systems enable a better understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes?
Enablement.Answer: The datasets comprising long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with auxiliary hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, enable a quantitative understanding of these exchanges, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and maintaining ecological stability.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for the successful deployment of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers in monitoring turbulent fluxes in desert areas?
Enablement.Answer: The deployment requires the establishment of land surface flux and meteorological stations, as well as the integration of automatic weather stations to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data and hydrometeorological parameters.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be expected that long-term observations are necessary for understanding energy and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Long-term observations are indispensable because a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize oasis–desert interactions, protect ecological stability, and support the sustainable development of oases.

Expectation.Question: Why is there an expectation for challenges in maintaining ecological balance in inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent occurrences of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road.

Expectation.Question: Why might the data processing and quality control procedures be expected to be complex in datasets involving oasis–desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedures are complex because they involve a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems, including long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the methodologies employed to process the leaf area index data collected through wireless sensor networks in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The methodologies employed involve processing raw light data collected by sensors into usable leaf area index values through software that identifies and fills invalid data, applies a 7-day moving average to mitigate weather impact, and averages node data within sub-areas to produce final observations. This approach seems rigorous in managing data integrity and accounting for environmental variability.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how effective are the data collection strategies using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: Eddy covariance systems and scintillometers are effective for capturing detailed flux measurements due to their ability to provide high-frequency data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange. The use of these techniques, combined with auxiliary data from automated weather stations, offers comprehensive insights into ecosystem dynamics, although they require careful data processing and quality control.

This includes half-hourly turbulent flux data acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, as well as hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the challenges faced when collecting environmental data in arid and semiarid regions.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in collecting environmental data in arid and semiarid regions include ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, particularly in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and summarize the data collection methods utilized for gathering leaf area index data in arid and semiarid regions, focusing on sensor technology and data processing techniques.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for gathering leaf area index data involve using the LAINet wireless sensor network, which automatically captures light data at each node daily and hourly. The original data is processed using LAINet software to compute daily LAI and undergoes further processing for invalid value identification, filling, and smoothing using a 7-day moving average to mitigate weather-induced variability.
